dialogues.text: {interrupts) This way please. He ushers her into a room where two officers stand 3 behind a table, waiting. On the table is an open suit- case. Mary looks at the suitcase and then the two men. The Senior Officer closes the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hail, hail, the gang's all here. What the heck is going on here, boys? Wait a minute, wait a goddamn minute -~ Is this some kind of Candid Camera thing? Huh? Where's the camera? She looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why, yes, I believe it is. ‘Those look like my old chinos -- with _- the rosebuds -~

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR OFFICER
dialogues.text: Then can you please explain how this came into your possession? The O£ficer holds aloft a piece of microfiim concealed in a bra.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Doesn't look like anything of Mine, although I'm such a sloppy packer, I'm not surprised at anything -~ The Senior Officer slaps Mary hard, sending her halfway across the room where she lands with her head down -~

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR OFFICER
dialogues.text: Did you think that your affair with a government official would go unnoticed? We are not fools, Miss DuBois. Mary slowly turns her head, regarding the Officer steadily. Her lip is bleeding. Her demeanor is com- pletely transformed. She is no longer a midwestern Carol Burnett dingbat, but Marianne DuBois, heroic political mole.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: That's your best evidence for not being foolish? You wish you were foolish -- foolish should be a goal of yours. But you're not even a fool; you're nothing more than a thug, a second-rate thug. The Officer starts toward Marianne as if to strike her again.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: {continuing) Go ahead, hit me. But we will survive. We have more spirit and more resources than you. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All it'll cost us is money, while you... there isn't enough mommy in the world to further a cause like yours -- Marianne pauses. A look of consternation flashes across her face. One of the guards starts to break, eausing the Senior Officer to blow. Finally Marianne starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE/SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Fuck... I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm sorry, Lowell ~- can you use any of it? No, of course you can't; there are no cutaways. You hate me now, don't you?

The door closes and an instant later, her stand-in slips out. We GO BACK to the soundman with the headphones around his neck. Through them we hear someone snorting cocaine. Both soundmen look at each other knowingly. One puts a finger up to his nose. He hears the SOUND of a TOILET FLUSHING THROUGH the HEADPHONES. Lowell is directing the Senior Officer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: It was very good, Raoul. This time, you know, when you Say Miss DuBois -- try not to punch it quite as hard. Be more victorious with your discovery than ominous. You're plenty ominous as it is. -

dialogues.text: Is the airplane in this shot ~~ or are you just glad to see me? i'm coming, I'm coming. (she subtly wipes her nose) Show business is my life -~ A blood ampule is thrust deep into her mouth.

dialogues.text: Now, there are a lot of people here trying to work together to make this a good movie. I expect you to pull yourself together for these last couple of days on this film and work with us or... I'll kill you. I'll kill you before you kill yourself. And I'll doa better job ‘cause you're so out of it you'd probably even botch that up. Now, do you think you can do the scene straight through this time? Suzanne just looks at him, humiliated and dumbfounded.

One more hit of cocaine on this picture and I'm going to make sure that everyone in this town who doesn't already know, knows what a fuck up you are. I'll ruin you forever. And then I'11 kill you.

dialogues.text: {loud) Suzannet Suzanne doesn't respond. pocTOR (continuing; louder) Suzanne! Suzanne, unconscious, tries from deep within her to become conscious. fhe Doctor slaps her hard across her face, Suzanne reacts. She mumbles.

Suzanne is being held down by a nurse. A black, Chalkish fluid is forced down her. Moments later hear her throwing up.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Funny. I just rented the video of "Mist on the Lake." We see Suzanne's vital signs. They are low. Her heartbeat slow. , we The Doctor's hand brings the hose into Suzanne's face.

dialogues.text: (continuing) She had french fries for dinner, t see.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: And some kind of meat product. And a pickle. They begin to insert the hose into her nose. DocTOR (continuing) She isn't going to like this; I don't care how unconscious she is.

dialogues.text: A woman is running down the hallway, wailing, every~ thing flying -~ purse, wig askew, blouse untucked, false eyelashes removed. Clearly this woman was caught mid-something for the apparent emergency. She is DORIS MANN, about 60, formerly beautiful and more than some- what currently. She was an enormous star in the 50's and 60's and bears that mark. o She is currently very upset, theatrically so. Cutting a wide swath as she makes her way down the hall -- things dropping out of her purse, mostly makeup ~- a pack of cigarettes. People watch her as she moves by moving aside to avoid impact. Doris Mann is very up- set. Perhaps she has lost a shoe.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: My baby, my baby. She is breathless. INT. EMERGENCY ROOM ~ SEVERAL HOURS LATER 1z Suzanne is unconscious following her procedure. She is still being monitored. An IV runs into her arm. Suzanne's mother, Doris Mann, has flung herself across her daughter's inert form. There is something childlike about Doris at the same time as she is theatrical. She is far from a monster as many stars from her generation have been depicted. She is tough, but at the same time, touching, almost adorable. She is a product of complete self-invention. Dirt poor to rich and famous. Though the following has a touch of theatricality about it, almost as though "done" for the two nurses ~~ there should be no doubt about Doris' sincere feelings and concern for Suzanne. Several NURSES try to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE A
dialogues.text: She's resting comfortably, Miss Mann. She should be (fine).

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (not hearing, interrupting) How did this happen? I was a good mother. I had my career, but I was there. She had a happy childhood. I can prove it -- I have films. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: al 12 13 16. CONTINUED: il

dialogues.speaker: NURSE B
dialogues.text: I’m sure she did, Miss Mann. Now if you'il just --

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: {interrupts ) Unlike her alleged father who was .- never there, just like he's not here now. Do you see her father here?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Of course not, He's not here, that's why. I’mhere. That's who. Me. Her mother. (goes to tuck Suzanne in) At least she's sleeping now. (to Suzanne) You never could sleep, could you? (kisses her) That's my girl.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE'S DREAM 12
dialogues.text: Suzanne is wandering down a hospital hallway. There are pictures on the wall. Marilyn Monroe, Lenny Bruce, Elvis Presley, Montgomery Clift, Judy Garland, Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, John Belushi, Jim Morrison. She regards them curiously. Suddenly she sees the nurses' station. It is empty. She looks around to make sure the coast is clear then makes her way to an enormous medicine cabinet, which she carefully opens. It is filled with pills. She starts dumping them into her hands -- but then she looks down and her hospital gown has no pockets to put the pills in. She panics that gomeone is coming. A woman rounds the corner, catching Suzanne in the act. The woman is Nancy Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne wakes up, horrified, sweating from her drean. A therapist, JULIE, is standing at the edge of her bed. She is middle-aged, dressed rather youthfully, with dark hair and very long red nails. She smokes Lucky Strikes. She is the queen bee in this rehabili- tation hive. She carries a pad and pencil.

dialogues.speaker: JOLIE
dialogues.text: Nasty dream? Everybody has those. You'll have them for a while. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (ironic) Great. Juiie walks over and opens the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (briskly) I'm Julie Marsden, Director of the Dawn o£ New Hope Rehabilitation Program. I'm here to admit you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Your blood work was done up in the emergency room the other night. Since you've been basically sleeping since then —— we're going to have to find out a couple of things before we officially admit you to the unit.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: All right, we'll start. She refers to her notes on a clipboard, as she sits in a chair at the end of Suzanne's bed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: A drug addict?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You've admitted yourself into a drug and alcohol rehabilitation unit. Surely that implies some sort o£ drug problem.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Drug problem. Yeah, I guess, but not... not a drug addict. See, T never took any one drug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (thinks a beat) I guess that makes me a drugs addict, huh? My doctor told me ft didn't so much have a serious drug problem as a drug problem I should take seriously. -

dialogues.text: (raises her eyebrows) I see. And did you?

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Take it seriously?

dialogues.text: Did you deliberately try to take your Life?

dialogues.text: (flabbergasted) What?!

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You know, kill yourself, suicide, overdose. Suzanne is affronted.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if my question offends you, but having to have your stomach pumped indicates fairly suicidal behavior. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Well, the behavior might be, but I'm certainly not. I always describe my drug taking as taming the beast. When I go to someone's house, I go to their bathroom, run the water and go into their medicine cabinet. If they have pain killers -- I take them. They're mine, I usually leave a few. I'm like Robin Hood. I take from the straight and give to the potentially stoned. Me. Julie makes a note.

dialogues.text: Do you always have to be funny?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No. Not unless it's a very serious situation. Then it's necessary. {I think they call it gallows humor. This way to the gas, ladies and gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) You're going to have to learn to handle a reality without drugs.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Hey, you teach me how to identify it, I'll try to learn how to handle it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Everybody has their own particular reality. Only you can identify yours.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Well, then we're both out of luck. I'm in the business of fantasy. My family's in the business of fantasy -~ Fantasy is my reality.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Why did you go into show business, then? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I didn't go into it -- I’ve never been out of it. But -~ (Suzanne puts up her index finger) I have a plan. If am planning an escape. [I am tunneling out of show business. Digging under all the major studios... Say, do we get any medicine to help us come off drugs? Julie gives her a look. Suzanne's

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I want you to know that I know you're seared and that this is the place to handle it. eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (humiliated) I don't understand how I almost died. That was never what Tf wanted to do.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What did you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Just... get out of everything.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: That's very different isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what to do?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: That's your first step to recovery -- is to recognize that you don't know. That your best thinking got you into an emergency room. But we've all been there. Here we're all recovering addicts and alcoholics. I've been clean for thirteen years. Off heroin.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (impressed) Heroin. Gosh. cuT TO:  14 2l. INT, DRUG REHABILITATION HOSPITAL — NIGHT 14 An oversized hospital room which serves as the family therapy room, or movie room, or cafeteria. Family night at the Dawn of New Bope Drug and Alcohol Rehabilitation Center in Century City. patients are seated in a circle on cafeteria chairs with two chairs in the middle. In the hot seat (center chairs) are ROB, an agent, and his wife, CAROL, the cocaine addict. JIM, a therapist, is conducting the session. He is an attractive, large black man in his thirties. Rob is impeccably dressed, down to his socks. He is an ambitious workaholic whose manner is arrogant and cold. Carol is a nervous gentle girl who is intim- idated by her husband. She chain smokes. Other addicts and their families sit and watch Carol and Rob in the hot seat.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (good~naturedly) It's nice to see you here again, Rob.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I'd like to say it's nice to be here, Jim, but...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I know it must be very unpleasant for you to have to deal with all this.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Of course it's not pleasant, but Carol feels that it's important for me to participate, so I come.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Iosee. But it's difficult for you to see the point, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Of course not. It's just that, as you know, this is Carol's second visit with you people and the first time I came down here happily. Carol laughs ironically and rolls her eyes. Suzanne watches Rob and Carol intently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Why are you laughing, Carol?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Buh?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: When Rob said he came down here happily the last time, you laughed. Why was that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (laughs again) Oh, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (confrontive) What, Carol?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Nothing. I don't know. I never felt you were happy to come here at all, is all.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: That's not true, dear. Tf specifically remember you noticing how involved I was last time. This time, admittedly, I'm not quite as enthusiastic. I have a lot more work that is impossible to interrupt as easily as last time and I know I don’t have to remind you that when we married we had an understanding that my work came first. You said that you could live with that arrangement. You know how important it is for me to devote a lot of time to my job in order to do well. And certainly you benefit from my success. Don't I give you everything you want? Don't we live in a nice house? All I ask from you in return is a little support and some peace and quiet while I read my scripts on Sunday. As this dialogue continues, the group looks very uncom fortable, squirming in their seats, particularly the women, and most particularly, Suzanne. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (barely audible) I know, I just... She trails off awkwardly, wishing she were dead or invisible. Carol can

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What? Tell me, Carol. I'm not a mind reader. I'm sorry I'm not able to be more attentive while you're in here. Didn't we go to Barbados last year for Christmas? Didn't I say you could re-decorate the house this year? But now, in light of the expense of the clinic, I'm not sure if that's still feasible.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (mortified) I know, but...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Is there something you'd like to communicate to Rob, Carol? hardly speak. There are tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nothing really important.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: {to group) Who here thinks Carol is having trouble communicating with Rob? Group raises hands.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Someone ought to bust him in the jaw.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Now, Carl. These random outbursts of yours do no one any good.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I don't really see how this process is of any benefit at all. Publicly airing one's difficulties ~~ (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: {interrupts gently) Does anyone here think they could communicate with Rob in Carol's place? Suzanne, who has been looking furious on Carol's be- half, raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: {continuing) Good for you, Suzanne. Rob, this is Suzanne who will be sitting in for Carol. Suzanne and Carol, why don't you trade seats? Suzanne and Carol trade seats.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {nervous ) Hi, Rob.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Good evening. Jim stands to one side, watching. The rest of the junkies look on breathlessly or not.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well? Carol watches fearfully from Suzanne's seat. Suzanne starts out haltingly and gains confidence as she continues.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: This is my first post overdose performance, SO bear with me. (clears her throat) I wouldn't feel comfortable telling you how I felt. I'd be afraid I might get it wrong. I might make a mistake and say the wrong feeling and then you'd correct me. You talk to me like I'ma child. So officious and grand. I can feel you massing on my borders; a Little backward country with a superpower poised for takeover. Russia to my Finland. The implication is that my way is wrong, that I can't do it. It's like dope. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't mean that's why I take it, but that's what it does. It takes you over, you lose control. It doesn't let you take care of yourself. Like you. You don't let me take care of myself by -* implying that I can't -~ never could. By implying that you -~ or anyone -~ could do it better. Nothing I do pleases you, so T do nothing to please you anymore. I'll spell relief any way I can. Tt can't be perfect like you. Tf use drugs to take me out of the game. I don't want to play if I Can't win. With you I always feel wrong and stupid and young. I can't win. As long as I stay sick I give you something to be. As long as I'm not good enough you're better. I doubt myself to the degree that you're sure. Well, get this, I'm sick of playing down to your up, failure to your success. Stop looking at my faults as a means of not dealing with your own. Feeling superior to me doesn't make you someone. You're Doctor Frankenstein... and I'm your monster, Frankenstoned. Get off my back. As long as you take care of me I'll never take eare of myself. Find a hobby, get a night job, become a Big Brother. Just leave me to myself. Get a life. Suzanne stops, embarrassed. Jim rescues her.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Thank you, Suzanne. You make a very lively Carol. Rob looks a little stunned. Carol looks a little pleased and a little frightened.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (continuing) Why doesn't everybody go downstairs and visit with their significant others ~~ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 is

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The group 26.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Their what??

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Their families, spouses or lovers. You have about fifteen minutes to visit. Carol and Rob, I'd like you to stay behind and talk for a moment, if you would. begins to disperse and move out of the room. Julie, who has been watching Suzanne sit in for Carol, Suzanne's motions her over to one side. new drug hospital pal, ARETHA, waits for 15 her. BART and ALLEN, two other family night partici- pants, sit talking.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: That was very good, Suzanne. Anger makes you eloquent. You showed genuine feeling for the first time here.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm always better as other people.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Why are you so afraid of feeling in yourself? SOZANNE. (uncomfortable) I'm a better thinker than a feeler, I guess. I'm just leading with my strength.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Maybe this strength just hides a weakness.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Oh Christ, why does everything have to be about something? I'm mental ‘cause I’m not emotional -- why can’t I be mental ‘cause I am? There are plenty of emotional people -- I bet no one asks them why they're not mental.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Where were your parents tonight? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: My mother, you mean. My mother is working. She's coming if she can. She's coming after work. And that is not the problem. That's the good news. She's a good worker, a great role modei for working, for being independent, for being tough. You leave her alone. If it wasn't for her, I don't know where I'd be. Certainly not where I am today. Julie just looks at her. Suzanne realizes what she has said -- where she is.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Deal with your feelings, Suzanne -~ before they deal with you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Do you always talk in bumper stickers -- or is that just on the job jargon?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You know, Suzanne, alcoholism is not the problem, it is the solution -~ but until you remove this solution, you can't see clearly what the problem is. This anger isn’t about me. Who are you really angry with? We hear Doris call gaily from down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, darling. Julie and Suzanne look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I told you she'd come. Suzanne is joined by Aretha. They both move down the hall to Doris -- away from Julie.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Hello, dear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is CONTINUED: (2) 15

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {to Aretha; sotto) Just when you thought it was safe to go back into the rehab. Suzanne moves to Doris and embraces her. There is true warmth between mother and daughter.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hi, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Am I too late for the family thing?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but that's okay. Let's go back to my room. 16 Doris and Suzanne start to move down the hall to 16 Suzanne's room. Doris in her highly coordinated semi-stylish ensemble and fur, Suzanne in her jeans and T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, sugar, I didn't want to miss that -- how was it? Aretha hovers to one side, Bart and Allen behind.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing; doesn't wait for her reply) What's the matter with your hair?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's all the rage in the rehab. At this moment they are approached by two gay men, Bart and Allen.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Suzanne, but could If meet your mother?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Sure, Bart. This is my mother, Doris. Mom, this is -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Oh, Miss Mann. TI can't believe I'm meeting you. Ever since I was about seven, I've wanted to be you.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Bart does you in his drag show.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: This is my lover, Allen.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (to Bart) What number do you do?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: "Whistling Pines.” Suzanne starts to move off with Aretha, a girl in her mid-twenties, who dresses very punk.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Mother...

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, boys... Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: See you later. Bart and Allen go giggling down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Sorry, dear. You know how much the queens like me. Suzanne, Aretha and Doris are walking down the hall to Suzanne's room.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Uh, Mom, this is Aretha.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. How rude of me. I'm just so excited to see my daughter. Aretha. What an unusual name.

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: I know. I think my family was expecting someone black. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The three women are now standing at the doorway of Suzanne's room.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Are you black?

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: No, 1... It's nice to meet you. Suzanne's told me so much about you. I'm going to weave a basket or something and let you two visit. Aretha exits down the hall. Doris and Suzanne enter Suzanne's standard issue hospital room.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: She seems very unusual. What did she say about blacks? Doris throws her bag on the bed and pulls out a pack of cigarettes. She looks around for an ashtray. Suzanne gets a paper cup, puts a small amount of water in it and hands it to Doris. Doris lights up, sits down and crosses her legs dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I think she was making a joke.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh well, I'm glad you're making friends. Now, did you call Mort?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Not yet. Suzanne gets on the bed and sits hugging her knees. She rocks back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, you should. You're supposed to start that movie.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm not going to do it. Doris gets up and starts pacing and smoking.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't think you should do it, and I'il tell you why. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Mom, I just said I'm not going to do it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: First, I don't think that this is a pivotal project in your career; two, you're going to need time to rest and explore; and C, I think you should change agents. f don't like what they're doing for you. Careers need planning. Your problem is you're too impatient. You're only interested in instant gratification.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Instant gratification takes too long.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (not hearing her) But I don't want you to think about any of this now. I'm handling everything while you're in here. No pressure. I want you to feel absolutely clear -- nothing hanging over your head. Doris' eyes suddenly fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh dear, look at me. I promised myself I wouldn't do this and now look. I didn't want you to see me upset. I hate getting upset. Tf just hate for you to go through this is all. I wish I could do it for you. I never wanted you to go through any pain. I tried so hard to shield you, protect you. I always worried that I'd lose you. That you'd be taken from me early.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: As opposed to later when it would be more convenient.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Golly, are you tough. Just Like Grandma. Always judging me. You've never forgiven me -~ 31. 17 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Ma, T don't think that we need to go over this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You never let me talk, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: It's just that I don't feel like I'm talking to you. I feel like I'm talking to your drama coach.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Don't make fun of your Aunt Sylvia, dear. She was wonderful at character breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (sighs) Forget it, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You should try not to be so mad at me, dear. Suzanne is silent, rocking. Doris picks up some of Suzanne's underwear from her open suitcase on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Ah, I'll just rinse these out. I brought some Woolite packets. They're so handy for the road. Suzanne grabs her underwear from her mother's hands.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Leave them. I can do them. Suzanne and Doris wrestle with the underwear for a moment. They gaze at one another silently for a beat. Suzanne's face is red. She isn't breathing. Doris breaks the moment by going over and retrieving her purse by the chair, talking as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm having some clothes and a quilt brought over tomorrow afternoon and your tape cassette thing for music. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary is coming over Sunday with a video machine and some tapes... and maybe a plant -~ it's so blah here, I don't know how you can stand it. Everything one color. Suzanne stands where her mother left her, not breath- ing, clutching her underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted room where all the windows have been shut and the lights are out. The junkies are watching a drug VIDEO called "Hooked On A Line" about cocaine addiction. All the junkies are present.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: And then I went from snorting to slamming.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah! That's my kind of girl!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: And then one night, I found myself sitting with a kilo under the floorboards and a gun in my lap. Girl On Screen speaks in monotone. She has very greasy hair.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: If they're going to get real people for these things, they should at least get interesting real people.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: ... with the air-conditioner turned up full blast, sweating with all the windows shut with cellophane.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, ARETHA AND SUZANNE
dialogues.text: watching video.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (whispers) t was up for this film. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Not ordinary enough. It's one of the reasons I turned to dope.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That's understandable.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Did you see the original of this with Merle Oberon? It's one of my favorites. fhe group laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: transformed with Doris’ additions. Satin and velvet quilt, pink tape deck, several plants, a trunk of clothes, etc. Suzanne is seated on the bed reading the "Big Book” of Alcoholics Anonymous. There is a TAP on the door and NURSE DOTTIE comes in with a huge bunch of flowers and a tiny stuffed dolphin tied to them.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Flowers for you, Suzanne! Big, pretty flowers! Suzanne rises from the bed. As the door opens, we become aware of Carl's ever- present voice. He is on the pay phone which is located just outside Suzanne's room. Aretha Follows Dottie into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: Who died? Dottie laughs as she puts the flowers on the window- sill.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Both of you almost did, for a start. Dottie goes out laughing and talking to herself in her singsong, annoying voice.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Big, pretty flowers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girls annoying. 35. 19 look at each other as she exits. Dottie is Suzanne is opening the card that came with the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (referring to Dottie) Big fish in a little rehab.

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: Who are they from?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (reading) They're from the guy who pumped my stomach.

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Suzanne hands Aretha the note as proof. A look of Aretha is

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: (continuing; reading) You are a warm and sensitive person. (looks up) He can tell all that from the contents of your stomach?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: T'd have to be sensitive to need all that Percodan. I'm tempted to marry him to tell people how we met.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Miss Suzanne. Your mama's on the phone. consternation passes over Suzanne's face.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {calls) fell her I'm de-toxing. watching Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, I am aren't I? You know something that drives me crazy? I can't remember how I got here. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know I left Wallis' party with someone, but I must have gone into a blackout ‘cause I can't remember anything about it and Wallis is out of town.

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. The last thing I remember doing was smoking dust in the office bathroom -- next thing I know, I'm handcuffed and in an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Why handcuffed?

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: Apparently, I threatened to rob a liquor store. I didn't have a gun, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the junkies are in the television room on a brief afternoon break before group therapy. Carl, Sam, Bart, Aretha, Suzanne, Carol, Alex and Sid. They are all glued to the TV -~ rapt, 4 lost generation has found its favorite TV show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPENING CREDITS for "The Outer Limits."

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION, (V.Q.)
dialogues.text: "you're traveling in another dimension. Not a dimension of sight and sound, but of mind. A place that lies between the pit of a man's fears and the peak of his imagination. There's a signpost up ahead. Next stop: The Outer Limits." We PAN SLOWLY across the faces of our junkies as they absorb “The Outer Limits.” Carl gets up and turns the channels. Everyone groans. A20 turns it to David Letterman. It is a re-run. Suzanne is on.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Oh God, turn it please! It's a re-run from last year. 1 can't watch myself. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: on TV. 37.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: No. Leave it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's watch it. What's the matter? You're great on talk shows.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: My personal tragedy. Great ona talk show. The JoAnne Worley of my generation. sID Shhhh.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: So your first husband was a nightclub performer?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I don't remember my first husband. { married him when I was seventeen =~ and then only because I didn't like my room. Audience laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {continuing) Which was also eventually grounds for divorce. I didn't like his room either.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: Well, in California those are standard grounds for divorce. Badly done rooms.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Don't tell my second husband that.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: That's right. You were married to -~

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Please. Don't mention his name. I made the fatal error of marrying an actor. Later I tried to get it annulled based on the fact that he wasn't a real person, but I'm not Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: But you actually worked together, didn't you? In Mist on the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Tragically, yes.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: There's a famous kiss in that. Let me ask you something -- did he use his tongue?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. He's much too famous to use his own tongue -— he gets someone else to do that for him. Audience laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: So what are you doing now? Suzanne, off TV, speaks to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm in a drug clinic. fhe junkies cheer.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {on TV) I'm retaining fluids for Whitney Houston.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Well, clearly she’s not retaining her own fluids ~~ who do you think is doing it. Audience laughs. Suzanne, off TV, hides her head and flushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hospital office. Julie sits at a desk with her chair facing Suzanne and Doris, who sit in other chairs. They have just begun a meeting. Julie has begun explaining something to Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: So the upshot of the whole thing is that, having been so recently in a clinic, you're a very high risk for a movie.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: But they want me to do the movie. I talked to the director and --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: The director isn't the problem. It's the insurance company. They refuse to cover you in the event you do drugs (and alcohol).

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I'm not going to do drugs and alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: We know that, dear. But these are businessmen who have no knowledge of creative personalities, Actors are not treated well, and actresses are treated like... Well, I hate to say the word, but... shit. Why, I remember when I was fifteen years old, Mr. Mayer called me in for a meeting and he was on the toilet, and we had to conduct the meeting with him on the toilet. You can be sure he wouldn't have done that to John Garfield.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (irritated) Mom...

dialogues.speaker: DORTS
dialogues.text: (to Julie) My daughter doesn't like to talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Miss Mann, maybe I'd better handle this.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: of course. She'll listen to you ~- you're not her mother. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, other actresses and actors have not come to work due to a drug and alcohol problem, and it's cost the insurance company 4 lot of money. Try to see it from their point of view.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I do see. I'm being punished.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: There is a difference between punishment and accepting the consequences of our actions.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What comes around goes around, dear.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (to her mother) How do you figure having my stomach pumped going around to my not working again?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Suzanne, if you'll let me finisher you'll see it's not all bad news,

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (sulking, to herself) What comes around goes around.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I talked to the insurance company this morning and they've agreed to cover you if you stay with a responsible party for the duration of the film.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Meaning what? I should stay here? Punch out in the morning and in at night?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It's not quite that extreme, Suzanne. They thought it would be appropriate to stay with one or both parents ~~ since your father lives in New York, your mother said you could stay with her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suzanne looks totally confused.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: She couldn't stay with her father anyway. He's worse than she is. {to Suzanne) Not that you're bad, dear.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Stay with my mother? What am I? A teenager?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Dear, I lived with my mother and father 'til I was twenty-three, and we all shared one bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Suzanne, maybe it would be better to wait a couple of months to go back to work. Go to your AA meetings and when you're feeling better equipped to deal with the world...

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) But I want to do this film. I can go to meetings and work. I do better when I work. I feel like I belong. I feel necessary. I know how to do that.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: She's just like me when I was her age. I did film after film. T never stopped. It was wonderful therapy after my divorce and my Miscarriages. O£ course, in those days, the material was better. (to Suzanne) I think, dear, to do a cop film at this point in your career is a poor choice. You've just done an interesting political film; don't you think now it would be wiser to relax and compose yourself like Julie suggests?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (But) IT want to work now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: pORIS My daughter doesn't listen to me. Forty-two years in the business and she doesn't listen.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You understand the conditions for doing this film, then? For the duration of the film, you stay at your mother's.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You can have your old room.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (ironic) Great. Okay, okay. I'll stay with her. You. Great. Okay. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What do you say? No pain, no gain.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No wonder I'm so hefty.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Hefty? If anything you're too thin. Look at me -- my stomach ~~

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I was kidding, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, I don't get your generation's humor half the time --

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I don't have a generation.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Then I suggest you get one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The junkies are playing volleyball. Sid, Aretha and Bart against Carl, Sam and Carol. Dottie supervises to one side on a blanket with a RADIO playing. MARK, a new resident junkie, pushes Suzanne in a swing. Mark is 18 years old and looks moderately insane. He has very bad skin and hair parted down the center.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: So, you're getting out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yup. MARK a" That's so cool. I come in yesterday, you go out tomorrow. Changing of the guard.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Addict relay.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You know, I identify with you. You seem different. Well, that's how I feel. 1 feel how you seem.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Did I tell you 1 was in prison with Manson?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yes, you told me.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: He feels different, too. He told me that.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yup. Right to me. “I'm different, Mark." He said that.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: So you're starting a movie soon, Cari said.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Next week.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: That's so cool. Are you nervous? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm always a little bit nervous; SO...

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You don't seem nervous. You seem different. Like Manson. .

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. That makes a certain kind of sense. Mark pushes Suzanne higher and higher. The light sparkles through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Did I tell you what Manson said about Redwoods?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yes. Mark pushes Suzanne high into the sky. We STAY in the sky. As we PAN DOWN, we hear... the BUSTLE of a film set~- 23 ting up. Men SHOUTING at one another, equipment being moved, generators humming, lights being set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several camera equipment and wardrobe trucks, prop truck, makeup and hair truck, toilet truck, catering truck, and one long trailer which contains six com- partments. These are the artists’ dressing rooms, all with names on the doors. Among the names are the stars' names, ROBERT MUNCH and SUZANNE VALE. We see a car approaching from a distance as we watch the hum and activity of the film set organizing for its first day. The station wagon that has been approaching now drives up. Suzanne is in the back seat with wet hair. The car is met by a young man with a beard, TED, carrying a walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Yep, she just got here. I'11 show her to her trailer. {to Suzanne) I'm Ted, designed to make your life a more annoying place to he.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {bowing slightly) Suzanne, designed to be annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (laughs) Then we ought to get along great. ved Leads Suzanne to the long trailer with the row of doors. Each door has a name on it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (continuing; indicating door) And this, of course, is your...

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) My hamster cage. Suzanne climbs the three little steps that lead into her allotted space. Ted follows her.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I was going to say resting place.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (laughs) My final resting place. I always suspected it would end like this -- alone in a tiny room with an air-conditioner, a toilet and an A.M. radio in the middle of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fhe little room is very little. Along one wall is a sort of makeshift bed with a cushion to lie down on or be used as a couch. There is a makeup mirror with a counter under it and a chair beneath that. There is a small closet on the left as you enter at the foot of the bed, and in the right-hand corner is a little room- ette containing a toilet and a sink. The air~- conditioner is over the door, the radio on the wall. fed stands in the doorway as Suzanne surveys her space.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Hopefully it won't end like this; it'll just middle.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, hopefully, it'll end ina large, air-conditioned room with an A.M./F.M. radio. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I know what'll cheer you up. The producer is coming to see you. I mean, one of the producers.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: How many producers are there? 7

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Three. The Father, the Son and the Holy Ghost.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: And which am I endearing myself to this morning? Before Ted can answer, a large man, JOE PIERCE, appears at the door and knocks. He is middle-aged and looks like someone's stepfather. He is followed by Rob Sonnenfeld, the agent Suzanne Lambasted in the drug hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Anybody home?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe Pierce. Just came to welcome you aboard. Ted squeezes past Joe and Rob as he exits.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (to Joe) Morning, sir. {to Suzanne) So, can I tell them you're about ready?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I guess. Joe Pierce walks into the trailer and sits largely on Suzanne's small trailer bed.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Any more people in here and we'll need a lubricant. Suzanne laughs uneasily. Joe laughs heartily, slapping his thigh. Ted exits. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (continuing; calls) See you later, Ted! {to Suzanne) Suzanne, this is my agent, Rob Sonnenfeld, who's just come to make sure we're all A-okay.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: {testily) We've met. Rob remains as aloof as possible considering the tight quarters.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (awkward) Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We just came by to say hello and make sure everything is up to snuff.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Everything's great.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And we're going to need a drug screen.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Joe shifts his large body heavily.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's not for us, you understand. We aren't worried about you at all. [It's that damn insurance company. They refuse to cover you without a screen.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Of course, we're behind you one hundred percent. It's just one of the formalities of the business.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I understand totally. Do you want urine or blood? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm sure urine will do just fine.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Great. Do you have a cup or something I can put it in?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry about that. The nurse'll come by and get it from you later today. Joe slaps his thighs and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, I'm glad we had the chance to have this little talk. Well, I'll leave you to get ready. See you out there.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks. We HOLD on Suzanne's face as she watches Rob and Joe disappear out of her tiny trailer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FILM SET
dialogues.text: Gaffers and electricians, setting up a shot around a large cactus. The lights are being arranged with paper in front of them or screens to dim the lights. Stand- ins are tied to the cactus. The D.P. checks the lights on their faces with his meter. He shouts instructions to his assistants, one of whom is checking the distance between camera and stand-ins with a tape measure. It's a movie set, for chrissakes. Suzanne wanders to the edge of the set, watching them set up. Her hair and makeup have been done and she is in costume. She looks rather attractive for an under- cover cop. Ted appears at Suzanne's elbow.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We're about ready for a line-up.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Are we going to get a rehearsal, by any chance? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I think you've got this film confused with a big budget film. The lower the budget, the fewer the rehearsals, the worse the food. Get the picture?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (from the song "Leader of the Pack") Yes, we see. Ted guides Suzanne over to the cactus and she is tied up to it with Robert Munch.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hi, I'm Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Morning. Robert. Rocky, the First A.D., shouts over the bullhorn.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Quiet please. We're going to do a block for camera, everybody. There's a lot of dialogue, so we'll need your total cooperation. Also, keep in mind, there are live snakes in this shot, so we'll need you to be very, very careful. Robert and Suzanne look at each other. Live snakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the end of the day. Suzanne is removing her makeup in front of the mirror and eating a doughnut and drinking a Coke. There is a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (calls) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your mom's here. Suzanne gives her reflection a perplexed look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne descends the little stairs to her tiny home carrying the doughnut, and gazes out to the parking lot in the dusk Light. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her mother's Cadillac is parked at the curb surrounded by a little group of crew folks. Suzanne approaches. We hear Doris talking.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I haven't been on this lot since tony Randall and I shot “The Ghost of Rubber Boot Farm" in 1952.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: It remember that one. You rode a donkey in it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, that donkey! I even remember her name. Stella. Stella the donkey. Her trainer couldn't get her to do anything. Except pee. All it seemed to do was pee. f said where is it all coming from? It can't be the straw. Doris sees Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, hello, dear, surprise. Your old mother came to pick you up, see? Suzanne flushes in embarrassment at her mother's public persona. She gets into the car next to her mom. Ted sticks his head in through the window. Doris kisses Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: So I take it you don't need your driver, Miss Vale.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, she doesn't. I'm her driver. I'm her reason.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Ted, this is my mother, Doris. Mom, this is Ted.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: A pleasure, Miss Mann. I'ma huge fan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sl.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You're a poet. "A fan, Miss Mann." You're a poet like my daughter. Have you heard my daughter talk yet? She's so verbal. Oh, of course, you've heard her talk; you're working with her.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Mom...

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm embarrassing my daughter. She hates when I taik.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Only when you talk about me like I'm not here. Like I've passed on to my great reward.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (to Suzanne) You know your call for tomorrow, right?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks. Doris starts the car. Suzanne eats her doughnut.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Bye-bye, all.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You shouldn't eat so much, dear. You're starting to look years older than yourself.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Great. I'll just have some heroin, then. No, better yet, some of that near~heroin that just came on the market. You know, like near beer?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You've made your point, dear. Don't let's fight. Well, how was your day, darling?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: They made me do a drug test.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I knew it. I knew you shouldn't do this film.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you knew I shouldn't do it because it was a bad film, not .- because they were gonna make me do a drug test.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't analyze like you do. It just felt wrong to me. I had a dream that it wasn't right. Suzanne rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I know you don't take my dreams seriously; not even the one that predicted your kidney stone. You know, I had a dream the other night that I was drowning. Sinking to the bottom of the ocean, with a heavy sequined dress dragging me down,

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to alarm you, dear, Ifm just trying to prepare you. You know, I didn't want to tell you before, ‘cause you were in the Clinic and all that, but you know the hysterectomy I had?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, the one last year?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: They found tumors.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (nedding) Fibroid tumors.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: But, isn't that normal?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Usually. Usually it is normal. But you know, dear, in our family all the women die young. All have weak systems.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: But Gramma's still alive.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Barely. And don't contradict me, dear. I'm trying to tell you I might not be here much longer. Tf don't want to alarm you, I just want to prepare you for my death.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Fuck me, what are you gonna wear.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: {not hearing her) It's important you understand how precious your life is. I left you my emeralds and the rehearsal hall in my will, so when I die, I can look down from heaven and watch you pay off your house. Although if you keep spending money like you do, I'm not going to leave you anything. Or if I do I'll leave it to you in trust.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Great. Then you can even have control from beyond the grave. How did we end up talking about your death from my drug test? Could we just not talk, Mother? I don't feel very well.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You should let Dr. Feldman look at you; maybe you have tumors. I had one the size of a grapefruit. (sighs) My own daughter won't even listen to me. If only you'd change back to my business manager, I bet you'd feel better. I certainly would.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill myself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Don't even say that in jest, darling. Particularly right after you've gotten out of a drug Clinic. People might take it the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris and Suzanne drive up. Many cars are in the driveway. It looks as though there's a party going on.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: It looks as though there's a party going on.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Surprise! I thought I'd invite a few people over to celebrate your coming home.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: But, Mom, I have to get up in the morning...

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: All right, if you want me to, I‘1l go in there and tell them all to go home.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The door flies open and Doris stands there with her arm around Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: {calls) My little girl is home!!! About twenty people or so stand around. Mostly friends of Doris. Also her friend Aretha from the clinic. Suzanne looks mortified. Her grandparents are there, PEARL and OWEN, as is her housekeeper/nanny, MARY, a black woman about the same age as her mother. Her grandmother is seventy-five. Suzanne's stepfather, Sid Roth, sits drinking and watching television. Sid essentially never speaks. Suzanne's grandmother, Pearl, is an extremely critical woman. Her grandfather, Owen, has the beginnings of Alzheimer's Disease, and doesn't quite know where he is, but has a general idea that he wishes that his wife (or whoever she is) wasn't there too.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: All converge on Suzanne. Except Sid who watches TV and Owen who smokes and perhaps plays some senile version of solitaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne stands outside with Aretha, looking in through the windows at the assembled guests. Suzanne is eating. Suzanne eats a lot now. Candy, potato chips, Coca Cola.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (chewing) I mean, there are people here I haven't seen since high school. Nor would I want to. Louis Karasik, for chrissakes! Where did she come up with Louis Karasik -- the last time I saw him, he threw up scrambled eggs out of his nose on the way to the library.

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: He looks like that guy at the (AA) meeting.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be fabulous if my whole class ended up in AA making coffee, cleaning up, praying. Suzanne's grandparents, Pearl and Owen, come out onto the patio. Owen is holding an empty can of cashew nuts.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: Let me look at you, lovebug, before your fat old grandmother hauls her rear off to bed. Pearl smells Suzanne as she embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mamm. You sure do stink pretty.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You're not going, Grandma?

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: Well, your mother's started drinkin’ her wine and unless I want to sit up all night listenin’ to her rattle off at the mouth, I thought I'd high tail it outta here. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PEARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, now that you're better why don't you try to get her to stop? Suzanne gives Pearl a look.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, I know, she's as ornery aS a2 mule, just like Owen.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: I heard that!

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: Well, you are builheaded, honey.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Hey, Grandpaw, want some more cashews?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Did I have some already? Pearl shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: He gets worse every day.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Who gets worse -~ I heard that! Get off my back, woman. I want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: We're going, dear.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Not with you! I wanna go home. (to Aretha) Are we going soon?

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: Soon, Mr. Harmon, very soon.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (to Aretha) Know what my daddy did?

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: {confused) What're we talking about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: (to Suzanne) I told you.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: I heard that! Get off my back. Yap, yap, yap, yap, yap. Yap, yap, yap, yap, yap. That's all you do all the live long day. Owen wanders back into the house singing. Peari shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) And the farmer hauled another load away.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: The other day he punched me when I was trying to put some clean pajamas on him. (embraces Suzanne) Well, babydoll, I'm gonna skeedaddle. {to Aretha) You ought to eat more, young lady. You're no bigger than a pound of soap after a hard day's wash. {to Suzanne) Good night, sugar. Have to let the dogs out. Howdy has worms. Pearl exits. Suzanne looks at Aretha.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I have nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: The same can't be said for the rest of your family. What's the matter with your grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Psychologically my grandmother -~ medically Alzheimer's. A very bad combination. He seems to be Losing every part of his brain except for the one that realizes that the rest of it is going. And what he doesn't notice, she points out. As though he's doing it deliberately. Like Alzheimer's is an evil vice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARETHA
dialogues.text: He should go to a senility detox unit. They could send him to meetings with other Alzheimer victims.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: AA. Alzheimers Anonymous. So anonymous, even you don't know who you are. "Hi, I'm... and I'm... I'm... uh... Hi, I'm... what're we talking about?" Suzanne laughs. Doris' drama coach, SYLVIA RICHTER, comes out of the house and joins them on the patio. Sylvia is ninety years old and very dramatic. Doris is very like Sylvia sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: There you are, Suzanne darling. Well, dear, I was just saying to your mother that your taking the cure makes up for everything. Give me a kiss good night, dear. Sylvia embraces Suzanne roughly.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (continuing) You remind me so much of your mother as a young girl in this light -- it makes me want to weep. In those early days at the studio, when she first came to me for elocution lessons. As soon as she walked in the door I knew she was going to be an enormous star. Just as I knew it about you, dear, when your mother brought you out at parties and you did the twist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Miss Suzanne, your mama wants you inside to cut the cake. Suzanne looks at Aretha. What cake?  32 33 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne stands in front of a cake of her face with candles around it. She blows out the candles, which had essentially made her hair look like it was on fire. Doris embraces her daughter proudly. Suzanne looks exhausted. A very gay-looking OLDER MAN starts up a chant.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Sing something, Suzanne! A large body of the group murmur: “Yes! Yes, sing!"

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (humiliated) No, really, please, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: C'mon, sweetheart. Do one of your old numbers from my act.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, Mama, really.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Just one number to please your old mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne is standing next to the piano, singing. Doris' accompanist, ROGER, accompanies. Her voice is soulful, beautiful. She holds onto the piano for dear life. She is almost visibly trembling. She keeps her eyes trained on the ground. Doris’ face is a mixture of emotions from pride to envy. Sometimes she mouths the words to the song with her daughter. She occasionally shushes the other guests, even if they aren't talking. As Suzanne fin- ishes her ballad, Doris is in tears. Suzanne is miser- able. She finishes and gives her mother a helpless, caught look. The song she sings is a baliad like "If I Loved You," "Skylark" or "Better Luck Next Time," a yearning, sad song.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: «ee SO don't say Better luck next time That could never be Because there ain't gonna be No next time for me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: All are visibly moved. The room explodes in applause. Doris runs to her daughter's side, embracing her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That was lovely, dear. I don't know why you don't sing anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I get so nervous,

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: But you shouldn't be. You've got a terrific voice -- a terrific talent -~ a much bigger talent than mine. Now Gary starts another chant.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Now, Doris, Doris, sing something! The room chimes in once again: "Yes! Oh, yes!"

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, no I couldn't. Really, it's my daughter's night.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (knowing she wants to) Go on, Mama. Sing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (to Suzanne) You think I should?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: All right. You sang for me; I'1l sing for you. (to Roger) "Gee But It's Good To Be Here" -- in A~flat. Doris wows them with her song, completely eclipsing Suzanne. She is a true performer -~ loving it, born to do it. Nerves of steel, she plays completely to the crowd. Suzanne watches. The room is electrified, whipped up as they can only be in the face of a great and true entertainer. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've been to Reno I've been to Beverly Hills And I'm here. Reefer and vino I've done ‘em all and my dear, I'm still here. I've stood in bread lines with the best, Watched while the headlines did the rest. In the depression, was I depressed? Nowhere near. IZ got through all of last year, and I'm here. She finishes on top of the piano, the assembled company cheering. We HOLD on Suzanne's happyr defeated face. Doris casts a long shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party has dispersed. Suzanne has miraculously escaped. She enters and closes the door behind her, looking enormously exhausted and relieved. She moves to the sink intending to prepare for bed. A voice startles her from a chair in the corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hi, baby. Suzanne jumps in fright and looks around, seeing her father, TONY VALE, seated in the chair. He stands. He is in his late fifties, short, dark and formerly hand~ some. He has tremendous boyish charm.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Jesus, Daddy, don't do that -- you frightened me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sorry, baby, you know I wouldn't want to upset my little girl.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I know. They move together and embrace. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You sounded great down there, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: How did you get up here?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know your old dad. Where there's a will, there's a way. (sings; low) “And down that way I'll wander ~- Wander, my love, to your side.“

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Dad --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I snuck into the yard and climbed a tree. Pretty good for your old dad. But they can't retire me yet. He lifts up his shirt, showing his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Feel. Suzanne reaches out tentatively, feeling her father's stomach.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Pretty good, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Pretty good. Why, it's hard as a rock. Well, maybe not a rock.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: A pet rock. Tony laughs.

dialogues.speaker: . TONY
dialogues.text: Oooh, there's that terrific mind again. You got a terrific head on your shoulders, baby.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I've got a head on my neck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What? (gets it; laughs) A head on your neck. (shakes his head in wonder) What was that thing you said that |. time? Something about a martyr?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (slightly impatient) A glib martyr. Dad ~~ What're you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can't I come see my daughter? Oooh -- you look great, baby. (whistles) That's some get~up.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: How'd you find me?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Your service in New York referred your mother's number, so I put two and two together and... I thought I'd surprise you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Well, you did. You really did. How come you're out here?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm meeting with Mory Shenk -~ you know who he is ~~ he owns the Marquis Hotel chain ~~ they want me to meet with them about putting one of my deli's in their hotels.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: That's great, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So, how's my little girl? still haven't done any drugs?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yup. You clean?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: As a whistle. You got a great body, baby -- just like your mom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Is there something you want?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do I have to want something to come see my daughter? Aren't you glad to see your old dad? You were always thrilled to see me when you were little.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I was always thrilled to see you partly because I never saw you enough. I mean, that often.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That was your mother's fault. I wanted to see you, but she wouldn't let me -- you were in Palm Springs or somewhere. Ugh, I'm defending myself and I don't want to. It's just that when you say things like that, you twist the knife in my heart. I mean, I dontt really care who hurts me, but when you hurt me -~

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Dad, all I said was that I didn't see you that often.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Remember your sixteenth birthday -- I bought you six fucking rings and you gave them to all your friends -- I had to pay them off.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I didn't give them to all my friends.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I was in love with you when you were a little girl and now your mother has turned you against me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, she hasn't. I do love you, Dad. I just don't see you that much. We were supposed to see each other a month ago. I calied you and you never called me back.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I never got a message. Who'd you leave the message with?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Some woman.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ah -- Margie.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Who's Margie?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The woman I've been living with for the past four years.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Baby, is there anyone in your New York apartment?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What happened to yours?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh that landlord is crazy ~~ he kept my furniture. Says I was screaming. I was screaming because my finger was infected.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: He's keeping your furniture ‘cause your finger was infected?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, he's an asshole. You know I wouldn't come to you if I had somewhere else to go ~~ and once this Marquis thing goes through, I’1l be out of your hair -~ Baby, when I get my money back, I'11 buy you castles and cars.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I know, Dad. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (sings) "My best girl is the girl who's got eyes like a stone." Give your old dad a kiss. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: {continuing) I'm telling you, kid, you got a great ass. (shouts) Bring me the head of Beverly Hills. I love you, Angel.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I love you, Dad. He starts to turn away.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Pop?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes, mommy?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What kind of after shave do you wear? Someone asked me and I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Vetiver.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Vetiver.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Good night, sweetheart -- thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (to herself) Vetiver. Tony climbs out of the window as Suzanne looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne is dressed and made up, about to do a chase scene through the desert in the rain. The soundman is putting a mike in the car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROGER, the hair dresser, wets down her hair, SIMON, the English director, approaches and crouches down next to Suzanne's open car door. He looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Hello, darling.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Hey, Simon. He looks at his hands. The soundman finishes and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's happening? Did you have to take a drug test, too? Simon looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, no. It's nothing really. They just... the producers saw the rushes last night and had some rather interesting notes. Roger gives Suzanne one last spritz, sees that Simon wants to talk to Suzanne privately and discreetly re- moves himself. Suzanne tries to seem calm.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Well, what?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Now, don't take it the wrong way. I saw them this morning and you were fine.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (gloomily) It was my first day.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (emphatically) It was your first day, absolutely. I couldn't agree with you more. The producers simply felt you should have fun with it. (he smiles) Just have more fun with it, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Simon, if I knew how to have fun with stuf£, I wouldn't be in therapy. I wouldn't need to take drug tests.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Now, now. I think they had some very interesting comments. Maybe I'm not saying it properly. What I think they meant is that you could own your performance. Make it more your own. Just sort of have fun. Suzanne stares at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Really? And here I thought everything I did had to be fraught with incredible torment. This is amazing. Why didn't one of my shrinks tell me this?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (patiently) Now, Suzanne, you shouldn't be in this business if you can't take criticism. Suzanne stares at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: But, Simon, please. Have fun with it. Don't you think I would do that with everything I did if it was at all possible? Simon puts his arm around Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: I know you can do this part. Just relax into it. Be yourself and you'll be wonderful. Simon kisses the top of Suzanne's head and walks off to talk to BUDDY, the D.P., as Ted arrives with a can of Diet Coke.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Nutrasweets for the sweet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You know what I think? Actors are the lowest of the low. Unless they have box office, in which case, they're treated with respect without being respected. Suzanne takes a swig of soda and pulls a candy bar out of her pocket, taking the wrapper off and taking a big bite.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) At least with me, there's an honest level of contempt. They don't respect me and they don't treat me with respect. Ted nods sympatheticaily.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You ought to be an assistant director if you want to sample the motherlode of contempt. And preferably a second assistant director. Ted takes Suzanne's arm.

dialogues.speaker: TED
