dialogues.text: {continuing) We need to get you touched up. You're in the next shot. Ext. BACK LOT OF STUDIO - THAT AFTERNOON 36 Suzanne is headed to the prop truck. She moves through the warm hum of the crew as they check lights, change lenses, position extras. She is humming "Gee But It's Good To Be Here" as she arrives at the prop truck for her Diet Coke. As she rounds the corner of the truck heading for the metal steps at the back, Suzanne almost collides with NEIL BLEENE, the youngest of the producers.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: {stepping aside) Well, fancy meeting you here. Neil Bleene, associate producer. Suzanne smiles a startled smile and goes up the steps. She gets a Coke out of the ice chest, opens it and stands on the edge of the truck looking down on Neil Bleene. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I understand my enjoyment levels are down. Neil looks at his shoes and clears his throat. NEIL . Well, no, we felt the performance ~ was fine, but... (he searches for the right word) You're holding something back.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {repeats solemnly) Holding something back.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: It felt like you weren't... that you didn't make a choice. You made a non-choice. Like you were concentrating more on not doing something than on doing something.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I've been in theatre. I've also directed theatre. I'm producing this basically to make money. I'm actually a theatre director. From what I was told, you spontaneously hit Bobby during a rehearsal, and Simon stopped you. I don't think he should stop your impulses. The other thing is that sometimes certain line readings are appropriate, like in comedy, it's a rule that inflections go up at the end. Suzanne kneels down to look in Neil's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: There's a comedy rule? Neil runs his hands through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Well, there's not necessarily rules so much as guidelines. (beat) You were very good in "Public Domain.* What did you do there?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ql.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (defensive) I had Benjamin Keller as my director and Magda Valnepov as my coach. Tf didn't have fun with it. We had a month of rehearsals. We worked very hard. We hardly ever relaxed. Suzanne stops, realizing she's gotten pretty defensive and loud. Suzanne jul spill her

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {continuing; calmer) Look, I may not take criticism well, but that doesn't mean I'm not hearing it. Right now, I'm storing it in my delayed response area, because it's hard for me. Tf wish I was someone who welcomed criticism and immediately understood its value, but I'm not and if I look unhappy about this, Iam. I've had one day of work on this and this is my second conversation about what's missing in my performance.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) We're talking about two minutes of film. Two minutes of screen time out of ninety.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Is it correctable?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (reassuringly) Come on, it's not as though you farted during all your dialogue and we all sat in rushes and said, “What's that noise all over her lines?"

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {ironically) I'm so relieved. That analogy has bathed me in relief. mps down off the prop truck, careful not to Coke. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Thanks for the acting tips and the pep talk. I'm feeling much more relaxed now. Suzanne heads back in the direction of the set, leaving Neil and his leather pants at the prop truck. We FOLLOW Suzanne as she takes a swig of soda and rounds another corner of a truck. This is the wardrobe truck. As she approaches the back of it, she hears what turns out to be Simon's voice. Suzanne slows, eavesdropping on the ongoing conversation. She pulls a bag of honey roasted cashews out of her pocket and eats them quietly as she listens to the two voices.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Can't you get her into a girdle or something?

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE MISTRESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not with that dress, sir. We might be able to use a pantyhose with a control top. Although, I'm net sure if that will be sufficient.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: All right, all right -- anything. Just try to do something. And we're going to have tO put her in pants instead of shorts. The tops of her legs are very... Simon trails off, searching for a polite term for the tops of bad legs. Suzanne stops chewing, in suspense. Somehow she knows they are talking about her.

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE MISTRESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bulbous. She has cellulite. Suzanne winces. Bulbous? Cellulite?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: I do wish we could get her to stop eating so much. But then, I suppose having just given up drugs, she has to do something. Maybe we could get her to start smoking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne stops eating. It is her they're talking about. Oh, God. pocket. She slowly puts the cashews back in her

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE MISTRESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are we going to do about the bed scene, Mr. Woodruff?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Cheat the angle somehow, I suppose. Her breasts are rather .. out of shape, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE MISTRESS
dialogues.text: I£ you have her on her back, like the script indicates, her tits will just move off into her armpits.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: How unpleasant. Well, perhaps you should purchase some sort of camisole or something. JI had no idea when I hired her that she was this... out of shape. Though, I suppose we couldn't have gotten her if she was still... in her prime.

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE MISTRESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I€ you'll forgive me, Mr. Woodruff, with her reputation she is lucky to have a job at all. She pretty much destroyed the career she had.’ This iS a break for her.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: I suppose you're right. It's sad, isn't it, really. She was so good in “A Night Full Of Shoes." Well, I hope all this isn't too much trouble for your wardrobe department. I'm almost sorry we didn’t get Valerie Rogers, at this point.

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE MISTRESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Valerie has a terrific body.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Yes. Well, Alma... I must get back. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suzanne hears Simon START TO EXIT the truck and moves away quickly. A tall, thin MAN approaches her from the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Suzanne) George Lazan. Executive producer of "Kitchen Sink." How are you?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Fine... Suzanne ——

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {interrupts) Vale, I know. Anyway, have I caught you at a bad time? George is silent for a moment, then just suddenly launches into the purpose of his visit. He walks as he talks. Suzanne follows, puppy-like.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, look, I saw the rushes and frankly, you're holding back. See, I think of this piece as a light fluffy piece, a kind of “What's Up, Doc?" for cops. So you just gotta relax. You gotta just enjoy yourself and trust the process. ; Suzanne is incredibly uncomfortable as she walks along~ side George Lazan through the back lot of the studio.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (evenly) Well, I can't promise you I'm going to turn in a Barbra Streisand performance.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. You see, I think of Robert Munch as a kind of Ryan O'Neal type. He's a reactive actor. What we need is for you to be the one who governs the pace of the piece. If you dictate the pace, then Bob will follow you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I hardly think I'm responsible for the pace of the piece.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {impatient ) Well, look, it's a "Happened One Night" kind of thing. You know what I mean. Look, do you think you can do this part?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (tiny voice) Yeah. Why?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I always ask my actors that. Look, just because we imagined Goldie Hawn or a Marilyn Monroe kind of thing in this part... now we've got to deal with what you have to bring to it. We hired you, now we have to go with what you have.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (sighs) I appreciate your comments, Mr. Lazan. I'11 certainly give relaxing my best shot. If I'm not enjoying myself, though, it's not because I'm deliberately trying to sabotage your film.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I realize that. Just do the best you can. Oh, and, by the way, don't worry about the nose.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {touches her nose) The nose?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've been talking to the cameraman and we can straighten it with lighting. You'll barely see the bump.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Great. God bless you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We NOTICE a car and driver parked across the street. George sticks out his hand for shaking.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll see you on the set.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yes. George turns and climbs into the car waiting for him. The driver holds open the door. Suzanne watches him go. Suzanne walks back onto the set and approaches Simon.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Hello, darling. What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (stern) The problem, Simon, is that hundreds of people have had conversations with me concerning my low enjoyment levels and my nose... and... and it bothered me. I would prefer to receive direction solely from you. Simon looks concerned and the wind almost blows off his straw hat. .

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (affronted) Really? Hundreds of people? That shouldn't be. I'll have to have a word with them.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I mean, we're talking about one day of work here. A scene where I was tied to a cactus and assaulted by snakes all day. As if I were a child! I mean, why don't I give them my mother's phone number? She can stand by and make sure I'm relaxed! Simon snaps his fingers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: That's it! This is exactly her! This is the quality I want for your character. Right there. What you're doing now. See?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: But, Simon, this is not relaxed. This is incredibly upset. If this is the quality, then maybe... Simon puts his arm around her and walks her toward the platform where the crew waits.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Darling, just be yourself and you'll be fine. I know it sounds trite, but trust me. I'll talk to the producers and make sure what occurred yesterday is not repeated. Now try to calm down. Suzanne looks at Simon like one of them is insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne is once again removing her makeup at the end of a long, overwhelming day. She takes a last look at her reflection, and then exits her dressing room/hamster cage.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BACK LOT STUDIO SUNSET
dialogues.text: Suzanne is walking down a western street, then turns a corner into a suburban street, reminiscent of “Leave It To Beaver." Jack Burroughs appears behind her, catching up to her. Suzanne looks at him blankly for a second. She has no idea who he is. Then seeing as how she'd better con- ceal that fact until, through conversation, she can best determine his identity, she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hit

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's me. Jack. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Sure. She clearly doesn't remember and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Jack. How've you been?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good, good. You?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE

dialogues.text: C'mon, honey, it can't be that bad.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, it’s just... it’s about this guy.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: It usually is.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Bobby said you might know him.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I guess I might then. Who?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Jack Burroughs. Evelyn makes a small expression of dismay and amuse- ment.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know him...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: You might say that.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You've... slept with him?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know how much of a rest I got. Evelyn looks into Suzanne's face. Something in it frightens They both her.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Why? ~~ What's the matter? Has he got -~ (AIDS)?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) No, no, no... I mean, God, I hope not. walk for a beat, contemplating death.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: God, you scared me for a minute, I thought you were from some celebrity AIDS notification board or something.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: (thinks a moment) You mean asking me who I sleep with isn't personal anymore? What do you want to know -- if I smoke?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: When did you see him last?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I don't know. A couple of days ago. Saturday. Saturday afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (echoes) Saturday afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yeah, why?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I was with him Saturday night. That's two girls in one day.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: (laughs) And that's just the ones we know about. Imagine what you could pick up about him if you got one of those satellite dishes.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: How can you laugh? It's disgusting. Especially in this day and age.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: (reassuring) You look like someone that can take care of herself. Buy some condoms. Don't feel bad. He probably really likes you. He Gidn't give you his big Chekhov speech, did he? The one about light hair and dark hair?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: See, that's a good sign. That's his standard pick up line. That and the big Peru speech and the thing about smelling like Catalina.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: That I've heard.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Well, that's not bad. One out of three. You're obviously getting some new stuff, which means he must like you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: But, so, he goes out with a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Well, sure, that's his big thing. Women. And if you can just accept yourself with him like he's enjoying himself with you. That's what I do. I'm in it for the endolphin rush. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Endorphin.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne and Jack sit on the bed fully clothed watching *The Outer Limits” (or "Star Trek") with deep concen tration, reminiscent of our junkies in the drug clinic. Jack nurses a beer and smokes a joint; Suzanne sips a diet soda.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (watching TV) I saw someone you know the other day.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (watching TV) Really? {a beat) Who?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Evelyn. Evelyn Ames.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? He sips his beer.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where'd you see her?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: At the set. She's in the movie I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How's that going?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Okay. Now that my relaxation levels are stabilized.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Those assholes. I don't know how you can stand them.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I don't either. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I would have quit.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You can't quit. You know that. I£ you quit no one will hire you again. I like working, So... She shrugs, watches TV. Jack takes a hit on his joint.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bmmm.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I like Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I know. She told me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: {laughs) She told you?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: She told me you fucked her. Saturday. Saturday afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, here you go. Straight from fucking her on Saturday afternoon to fucking me on Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't realize you had exclusive rights to me.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What ever happened to discretion? What ever happened to moderation?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, I can't vouch for moderation, but as far discretion goes, what were you and Evelyn doing, comparing notes on the set? Suzanne gets up and starts putting on her sweater and her shoes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack gets 102.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: We weren't comparing notes. She told me she fucked you Saturday afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Just like that? She just marched right up to you between scenes and blew her wad? Or did you nose it out of her?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: She said she was in it for the endorphins. No, I'm sorry ~~ endolphins. off the bed and goes over to Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You said you loved me!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I meant it at the time. I do!

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What is it like a viral love -~ a 24 hour thing? Apparently Evelyn smells like Catalina too! [I guess it's going around? I just got out of a drug clinic -- how could you manipulate me with this shit about feelings?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Give me a break -- we just met.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: That's what I said to you!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (interrupts) This is ridiculous. I think we should can this little topic. Tf don't like this side of you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm not a box. I don't have sides. This is it. One side fits all. Suzanne starts out of the bedroom. Jack follows her. 48 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're very competitive, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, and I suppose you're not.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You're just a reaction to me, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I bet you got as Far as you did in show business by not being competitive.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's not competitive. That's ambition. Ambition combined with talent. Jack follows Suzanne through his house, toward the front door and down the driveway to her car. This should take a while, as it is a large house. She walks

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I£ you do say so yourself!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You know what this is? This is just a jealous tantrum.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm not jealous, I'm humiliated. How could you fuck me and Evelyn Ames on the same day?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What especially bothers you? That it was on the same day, or that it was Evelyn Ames?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I have to stop this. I have to stop this with you. out the front door. 49

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: {ironic) Are we breaking up?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: We can't break up, we were never together.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That should be news to you; you're acting like a wife.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: It's better than acting like a whore.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're in no position to judge me. How dare you lecture me about moderation -- you just got out of a drug clinic.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Where you fucking belong! Mr. Pothead, Mr. Vodka, Mr. Bedroom Eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hal What're you, 4 virgin? You weren't too hard to convince that first night! Suzanne gets into her car and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I thought we didn't do anything that first night.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I lied.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You bastard.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Great. You know, you were much nicer when you were loaded. Not so goddamn tense, with a fucking stick up your ass. Call me if you get a hold of a couple Valium. Suzanne starts her car and drives away.  50 51 52 53 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne drives; she is extremely upset. What's the use? Fuck it. At least when you're loaded, you can't feel how weird your life feels. She drives up to her mother's house and parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne sneaks into the house quietly. The house is quiet. She tiptoes down a hallway lined with pictures of her mother with other celebrities -- younger -- in films -- plaques commemorating her, etc. She sneaks into her mother's room -- Sid is sleeping with the television on. Where is Doris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne sneaks by their bed, careful not to wake him. And into:

dialogues.speaker: INT, DORIS MANN'S BATHROOM 53
dialogues.text: Suzanne fumbles quietiy in the dark for the medicine cabinet. She opens it. It SQUEAKS. She pauses, listening. Nothing. No one stirring. Sid still snores loudly. Suzanne peeks into the medicine cabinet for pills. Sees some Darvon. Not her favorite, but why not? She removes the bottle, opens it. Pours pills into her hand and pauses. She looks at her face in the mirror. Is this what she wants? No. But some~ thing. She must have something. She puts the pills back into the bottle, puts the bottle in her pocket, closes the medicine cabinet. This time, however, it makes a loud SQUEAK.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who's there? Suzanne rolls her eyes. Great. Caught in the act and she didn't even do it. The light flips on and Doris stands there.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Hi, Mama. I was just looking for some aspirin. Doris eyes her daughter suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Good. They eye each other. Suzanne exits. Doris follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris and Suzanne enter.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I have some news, dear.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What happened? You dreamt I lost some weight? Endorsed a line of clothing? Did an exercise tape for alcoholics? Suzanne gets a Coke and some cookies. Doris gets some wine from the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Don't be fresh, dear. Have you forgotten that you have looping this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {clearly has, sotto) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How do you expect to get anywhere in this business if you don't show up? Dear, I have something... inevitable to tell you and I don’t want you to be angry at me for predicting it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Your beloved business manager, Mort Wiener, the man you insisted on staying with and the one T begged you to leave --

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Mother, just skip to the part where I'm an asshole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I see no reason why you have to use language like that, dear. TI do wish you would try to avoid it. I£ for no other reason than I am starting to employ some of those words myself.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Mother?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yes, darling?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: The news.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I know, dear. I'm not anxious to tell you, because I know how upset you'il be. I know how upset I am. Mort Wiener has disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Disappeared?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: The police called here today to say that he couldn't be found and neither could any of his clients' money.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Meaning what? That I have no money? Can't they find him, can't I sue him?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm telling you everything I know, dear. I, of course, have contacted your stepfather's lawyer, Samuel Stone, who's terrific, and so he's on it now. But I’m afraid for the moment there's nothing more that we can do.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What does this mean? That I'm broke?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Not broke, per se. Your salary for this film is still in escrow, pending your completing it without a hitch =~ thank God, and, of course, you have your New York apartment, that you own outright, | thanks to me. JI£ I'd left it up to Mort, the bank would own that place and then you'd really be strapped.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: It sounds like I'm pretty strapped now. Oh, it's perfect. This is perfect. Thank God I got sober now, so I could be hyper conscious for this series of humiliations, this... this purification process from Hell.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It's no good feeling sorry for yourself, dear. You'll have to overcome these difficulties and you might as well do it with some style. You know, you could easily make an enormous amount of money if you'd only sing. You have a God-given talent that you just throw away. You could be as big a star as that... that Madonna girl. She hasn't got half your voice. I keep telling you, if you would only make an album, I could produce it. We could make one of those videos. Suzanne has heard this speech before and it drives her crazy. She might mouth some of the words as her mother recites them.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I'm not going to be a singer, Mom. I'm getting out of the business. If I don't, I'll never have any kind of chance at having a normal life.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Now let's take this one thing at a time. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suzanne is 109.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First, everyone is always getting out of the business, and B, you're just like me. Some days I wake up and feel like I'm talking to my armpit.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Could you please stop telling me how to live my life for at least a couple of minutes? Isn't it enough that you were right? Now you have to deprive me of some precious stolen moments of self pity for having lost my money?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Stolen moments?! You've been feeling sorry for yourself half the time for having a monster of a mother like me. Everything about you says look what you've done to me --

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Mother, I never said you were a monster.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, you don't say it; you're even too smart to think it. But, you feel it. You somehow lay the entire blame of your drug taking on me.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I do not, Mother. I took the drugs, nobody made me.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, sure, that's your logical brain telling you that, but in your heart you feel that I'm an... alcoholic and that's what's to blame for your... weakness, isn't it? silent.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Go ahead, say it -- you think I'm an alcoholic! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Mother... Okay. Poof! I think you're an alcoholic. Happy now?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I was an alcoholic -- when you were a teenager. I had a. nervous breakdown when my marriage failed and I lost all that money. But I got over it. Now I just drink like an Irish person--

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {interrupts ) I know, I know, like an Irish person -- you just enjoy your wine -- you drink to relax -- you've told me.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Don't be fresh.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Is there a cut off age for fresh or does it just go on indefinitely as long as you have older relatives? You don't want me to be a singer Mother, you're the singer -~ you're the performer. I can't compete with you. What if somebody won? Oh, you want me to do well -- just not better than you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Maybe you're just jealous, cause I gan drink and you can't take drugs anymore. I can handle it and you can't.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Handle it!?! How the hell do you handle it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (interrupts) My drinking doesn’t interfere with my work, like it did with you. My drinking doesn't interfere with my life.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What do you call this?!? 110.

dialogues.speaker: S4
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lil.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I cali this... You're sitting in judgement over me. What I do is my business. What I drink is my business.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: And what I do is mine. I£ you want me to get off your back, then get off mine.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm your mother!

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: And I'm your daughter! And I'm long past the age where it’s appropriate for you to tell me what to do. Look at this! A woman my age, struggling to grow up -~ to break free of her mother! This is tragic.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I wish my mother had been as concerned about me when I was a girl.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Your mother beat you and locked you in closets!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: One closet! And she didn't beat me, she used a strap on me sometimes when I talked back to her. You're lucky you had me as a mother and not her -~- if you think I'm tough.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, you'll do.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: And just what is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Nothing...

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, tell me, this awful thing that I did to you when you were a child! I want to know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You want to know? Pine. You gave me sleeping pills when I was nine years old.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I gave you sleep eze! Over the counter medication and I gave it to you cause you couldn't sleep!!

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You don't give children sleeping pills when they can't sleep!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: They're not sleeping pills, they're store bought -- perfectly safe! It's not fair to blame me for your drugs. I don't blame my mother for my misfortunes -- for my drinking.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You don't acknowledge you drink, how could you blame your mother for something you don't do? You know why I took drugs? Because I never wanted to end up drinking like you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: - Dear, I'm sorry if you think I Suzanne's hurt you. Everything I did, I did out of love for you. I may have done wrong sometimes. How can you do everything right? That time with the dress -- I'm ashamed of that. But what can I do? So, I made some mistakes, I'm human. You've never forgiven me for not being the perfect mother you thought you had before you were a teenager -- before my breakdown. eyes fill. This is true.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Please stop.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I£ I did wrong giving you those pills, I'm sorry. How was I to know? We didn't have self-help books then like they do now. The only place I had to learn from was my own childhood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suzanne starts out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where are you going? Suzanne, come back here, I'm talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm going to make an album, okay? I'm going to have some fibroid tumors removed, okay? I'm going to have a hysterectomy so that we ean break this chain of destructive, dominating women. I'm going to fucking loop! Happy now? Suzanne gets into her car and drives away. 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lowell sits behind a table with two other men -~ the editor and the sound editor. The room is in semi- darkness. There is a music stand with some script pages on it under a microphone. Also on the music stand are some headphones. Suzanne enters, slightly bedraggled and harassed.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: What're you sorry for?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Aren't I late? I thought I was late.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: No, as a matter of fact, you're early. We weren’t expecting you for another half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Oh... but... go... is it okay now? Lowell looks at her strangely. Almost with compassion.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Yes, it's okay now. Lowell pushes an intercom button.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Victor, Miss Vale is here, could we put up her reels now, please. (back to Suzanne) There now, wasn't that simple? Suzanne, this is our editor, Phil Hartley, and our sound editor, Elliot Morse. Suzanne and Phil and Elliot shake hands and exchange greetings. Suzanne continues to look uncomfortable as the scene progresses. As though she had sand in her soul.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ready, Lowell.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Victor. {to Suzanne) Well, shall we begin?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Okay. Suzanne stands in front of the little music stand.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: You're really much better in the film than you deserve to be. Suzanne looks distressed and nods.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Good. I mean, thank you. I'm sorry that I was such a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Well... you seem -- better now.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Really? No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Better because you're sober and --

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {interrupts) Worse because I'm sober.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Yes. But worse in a good way.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: fhe movie comes up on the screen that we saw filmed at the beginning of the movie only in black and white. Suzanne is being slapped by the prison guard. She flies across the room, turns her head slowly and says her speech. We see Suzanne see herself with a mixture of fascination and horror. Her eyes squint and she takes a step backward as though to protect herself from herself. This version of herself. She is good in the scene until she fucks up the line.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on screen) »»» We will survive any humiliation. We have more spirit and more resources than you. All it'll cost us is money, while you... there isn't enough mommy in the world to further a cause like yours --

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: That's as good as it got all day. We didn't get one full take after that. You only got progressively worse.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I know. I'm... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Don't be sorry... fix it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What? Lowell motions for Suzanne to put on the headphones.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh. Suzanne puts on the headphones and they run the film back. Suzanne watches herself backwards. The film starts forward again. We hear the three beeps before the words "there isn't enough mommy in the world" and after which Suzanne says it correctly.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) There isn't enough money in the world. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Let's look at it. The film is run again. This time with the sound cor~ rection. It is “perfect.” Normal. It has an odd effect on Suzanne. Her eyes fill with tears. She controls herself and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Lucky for you we can cut away to the guard. Lowell looks over and notices that Suzanne is more than somewhat upset. He very quietly sends the two editors away -~ clearing the room. Lowell moves to Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: (continuing) What could possibly be the matter? Here you've gone back and corrected the past -- at least in your work. What could be a better metaphor? It couldn't be something I said.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {cerying) Nothing you to say to me is as horrible as what I say to myself and at least it's happening outside my head where I can deal with it easier.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: So, what is it? Do you want me to abuse you more?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Help me. I can't do it. Any of it. I don’t know how and I can't ask.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: What are you doing now?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Don't you get it? I just know how to talk. I give self-awareness a bad name. You've got to find me in back of what I'm saying. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: The trouble with you is you've had it easy and you don't even know it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, I do know it. That's the trouble. I torture myself over it.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: You're not going to get too much sympathy from anyone. Do you know how many people would give their right arm to be in show business? To lead the kind of life you lead?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: The trouble is I can't feel my life. I can see it all around me and I see that so much of it is good and I just... take it the wrong way. It's like this thing with my mom -- I know she does all this stuff ‘cause she cares about me, but I can’t seem to... believe it. And... other stuff. Lowell hands Suzanne a Kleenex and she blows her nose hard.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: I don't really know what's happening with your mother, but maybe she will stop mothering you when you grow up.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You don't know my mother.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: No, but I know you. You could make a mother out of anybody. Look, your mother did it to you and her mother did it to her and back and back and back all the way to Eve and at some point you have to just stop it and say, "Fuck it, I start with me."

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Did you just make that up? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: I was working on it when you came in. If£ you'd come a half an hour later when you were supposed to T could have made it better.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: It sounds pretty good as it is.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: You just like it ‘cause it sounds a little like movie dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's me. I don't want life to imitate art, I want life to be art.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Look, look up on the screen. See what you can do? And you weren't even conscious then. Imagine what you could do now.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Maybe I should just go back into the clinic.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Speaking of art? Look, growing up is a process, not an event. It's not like in the movies, where you have a realization and your life changes. In life you have a realization and your life changes a month or so later. Lowell and Suzanne look at each other. They look

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: So, I just have to wait a month?

dialogues.speaker: . LOWELL
dialogues.text: Of course, it all depends on the realization. Some of them, you only have to wait a couple weeks, maybe. at each other. How did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's better out here coping than in the clinic giving up -~ ‘cause you'll end up out here coping eventually anyway. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So why not start now? Anyway, you can't go back into the hospital, I have a job for you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: A job? You wouldn't be ashamed to.- work with me again?

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Well, it doesn't start for 4 couple of months, so you have Plenty of time to have your realization, grow up, and leave your mother. Although I must admit I was a little taken aback when you did a second rate cop film after you worked with me.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: How do you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: I know everything... Except. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: What? He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: You know. Suzanne smiles and nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne is feeling much better as she drives back to Doris'. The fever is broken. She is hopeful, inspired. Possibly the song “Don't Worry, Be Happy" is on the radio as she drives down Doris' street. At the end of the block, where Doris' house is, Suzanne notices lights. What is that? Police cars? No. Oh no. What's happening? Many people are in the street as Suzanne drives up. She rolls down her window and calls to a POLICEMAN.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (calls) What happened? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Lady plowed her car into a tree. Suzanne looks. It is her mother's car.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Where is the lady? Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'm her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: OPPICER
dialogues.text: She hit her head. Ambulance took her to Cedars Sinai. I'm afraid we had to book her for driving under the influence. Suzanne looks panicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne's old stomping grounds. Suzanne runs into the admitting area and up to the ADMITTING NURSE. Deja vu.

dialogues.speaker: ADMITTING NURSE
dialogues.text: May I help? (recognizes Suzanne) Ah yes, Miss Vale, your mother is just getting patched up. I'll take you to her.

dialogues.speaker: ADMITTING NURSE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid some members of the press have been alerted to your mother's presence here -~ and her arrest.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Great, A policeman is sitting in front of a door. Doris' hospital room. A Doctor comes out of the door with a chart in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ADMITTING NURSE
dialogues.text: Doctor, this is Miss Mann's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Ah yes, Miss Vale. Your mother will be just fine. A contusion -~- a superficial head wound. She's more frightened than anything else. Suzanne does not recognize him as the Doctor from her overdose.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Can I see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne enters. Doris looks tiny and frightened sitting in her bed. There is a bandage on her head. We are seeing her without her wig and makeup for the first time. She looks startled and vulnerable as Suzanne enters -- her eyes fill with tears. When she talks, she sounds very childlike and unaffected. Pearl sits on the bed near her looking victorious and smug. Sid sits watching TV, Owen sits playing solitaire or reading a Louis L'Amour novel. It is a tableau of vivid women and shadow men.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: There she is. My other monster. I can't seem to keep you two out of the hospital lately.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: {to Doris} Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: She's fine. She just bumped her head is all. She was worried about you, so, fathead that she is, she got into her car and backed it up a tree. TI don't know how I got into this family -- I got a wino daughter and a doped up granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Mother -~

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: (interrupting, to Doris) Oh, hush up. I swear, I don't know where you get it from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTTNUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: usher Pear 122. 60

dialogues.speaker: PEARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Suzanne) But you. You're just plain spoiled. All your advantages and you just throw them away. (to Doris) I told you not to bring her up that way, but would you listen? No siree Bob. Well, don't come running to me ~~ neither of you. I got my hands full with Grandpaw -~

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Shut up, Gramma.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I should think you would.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: {to Doris) You see there? You should have washed her mouth out with soap when she was little like I told you. Then maybe she'd have some respect --

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I'm simply suggesting we try to enjoy each other without trying to assign blame.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: (to Doris) Woooo, Listen to Miss Snooty Britches. "Assign blame." Doris gives Suzanne a helpless look. Suzanne starts to 1 out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: (continuing) And just what do you think you're doing, young lady?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Moving you out of here and into the waiting room. Suzanne physically ushers Pearl out of the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: There's no need to shove, I'm going. You know what you need? A good pop on the butt like I used to give your mother -- Pearl is gone. ce

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Yap, Yap, YaDe Yap, yap, Yap, yap, yap, yap, yap. Owen continues reading and perhaps smoking. Sid continues watching TV, perhaps noting briefly that Pearl has exited.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I£ I thought I made you feel like that, I'd kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Don't even say that in jest, Ma. Particularly while you are in a hospital. People might take it the wrong way. Doris recognizes what Suzanne said as something she said to her earlier. Both women smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I suppose she means well.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: She sounds like that voice in your head that tells you you can't do anything.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yes. That's true, isn't it? Where did you go to?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Looping. I shouldn't have gone that way. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You don't really think that I don't want you to do well, do you, dear?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, Mama. And you were right about that guy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I’m right about your doing a music video, too. Just wait and see. That's where your big success will come from. Oh, dear, there's blood on my wig and all my makeup has come off -- look at me. Dol - have any eyebrows left?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Let's see. Suzanne sits on the bed and looks at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Some. It's not all rubbed off.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I hate having no eyebrows. Ever, since the studio shaved them off and they never grew back. Suzanne goes through her purse.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's put some makeup on you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Are you less mad at me now?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: I'll always be less mad at you, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You know, dear, I'm really sort of... jealous of you. You know, because, well, it being your turn. It's your turn now and it's tough for me to face that mine is almost up. It's so important to enjoy your turn, dear. And it would help me so much to know that... one of us enjoyed her youth. Suzanne applies base on her mother's face ~~ avoiding her little bandage.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you have a mirror? Suzanne hands her a mirror. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, my lord, look at me. Tsch, tsch, tsch. You know, I don't mind getting older -- I never thought I'd live this long ~~ but what I do mind is Iooking older. _- Do you have an eyebrow pencil? Suzanne hands her mother an eyebrow pencil.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's in my will that they don't bury me without eyebrows. I don't go in the ground without them. Doris draws on her eyebrows. Suzanne brushes Doris' hair back in a knot. Doris pulls at the flesh under her chin.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Maybe I should have that lyposuction under here...

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: There's press out there, Mama. Doris looks dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I figured. The Enquirer, I bet. The Star.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Doris Mann in drunken brawl with tree.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Doris Mann, still distraught over divorce from Tony Vale twenty-five years ago, attempts suicide with lethal oak. Both are laughing. Doris applies lipstick. She is beginning to look like her old young self. Suzanne ties a scarf around her head -- turban~like, concealing the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: We should get a family rate at this emergency room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: At least. Doris turns and faces Suzanne. She looks like Doris again.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS -
dialogues.text: (continuing) How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Great, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Not bad for an old-timer. Never let them see you ache -- that's what Mr. Mayer used to say. (she frowns) Or was it ass? Never let them see your ass. Anyway -- get your old mother her shoes, dear. Suzanne gets her mother's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay, baby, let's go get ‘em. Suzanne opens the door. Doris walks toward her, finishing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know what my mother said to me yesterday? She said that I put on airs, that I use big words like devastate and gesture. I don't think those are so awfully big, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: No, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do? Sound like a hick all my life just to make her happy? Doris walks to the door. Owen sings.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (sings) And the farmer hauled another load away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, well, compared to the end of the world. It seems to take a erisis to bring us together lately. sID Like war buddies. - Doris and Suzanne exchange a look. Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Sid speaks! ports Don't laugh, dear, he's also a dynamo in bed. Still waters, you know. (she sighs) ~~ Do you see my scarf? Oh yes, I’m wearing it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: Mama, what does no siree Bob mean? Both women walk through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris emerges and strides down the hall. She is met by police and press. Suzanne watches her from a slight distance, impressed. She is joined by the emergency room doctor -- JESSE.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: She seems to be feeling better.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: We're designed more for public than private. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Did you ever get my flowers? Suzanne looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: SUZANNE
dialogues.text: You're not...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (nodding) I pumped your stomach.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suzanne, in character, comes out, stands before the microphone and the band begins to play. She introduces her song and starts to sing. The audience ignores her. The mirrored ball sparkles through the smoke filled air. Waitresses serve drinks. As she continues singing, the audience gradually falls silent and listens to Suzanne, in character, sing. They are enthralled. § The CAMERA CRANES UP and we see the crew on various perches. MOVING CAMERA CONTINUES UP and FINDS, high on a catwalk, Doris watching. She smiles. END CREDITS OVER. Audience stomping, screaming and whistling.
